_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Michael Foods Norwalk - Norwalk, IA



Executive Summary



RMP Hazard Assessment Information

Anhydrous Ammonia is considered hazardous 40 CFR part 68. The same properties that make ammonia a valuable refrigerant, also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling this chemical to prevent unnecessary human exposure, and to reduce the potential impact or threat to nearby members of the community and or environment. Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle chemicals; combined with safety devices inherent in the design of this facility; and the training of our personnel.



The facility uses ammonia to chill glycol which is distributed throughout the facility as a refrigerant liquid. The ammonia liquid is fully contained within process piping and equipment in a closed loop system. Release scenarios were discussed as part of the Process Hazard Analysis and a Worst Case Scenario and Alternate Release Scenario were selected for Risk Management Planning.



Worst Case Scenario: The scenario is based on a catastrophic failure of the largest vessel and complete release of 46,895 lbs of Ammonia. Assumption parameters such as release duration (10 minutes), wind speed (1.5 m/s), atmospheric conditions (Stability F), temperature (25 ?C, 77 ?F) were specified by the RMP Comp The release rate of 2,580 lbs/minute was programmed into the RMP Comp Software that was used to model the Toxic Endpoint. A release inside an enclosed space was factored into the scenario calculation and reduced the release rate. The RMP Comp scenario calculator determined that the distance to the toxic endpoint would be 2.9 miles. The toxic endpoint and potential off site receptors are identified on the attached map.



Alternative Release Scenario: The scenario is based on a rooftop piping leak releasing 3,000 lbs of ammonia in a period of 30 minutes. The RMP Comp scenario calculator showed that the incident resulted in effecting a 0.2 mile area to its toxic endpoint. Assumpt

ion parameters such as release duration (30 minutes), wind speed (3.0 m/s) atmospheric conditions (Stability D), temperature (25 ?C, 77 ?F). The toxic endpoint and potential off site receptors are identified on the attached map.



It is this facility's intent to uphold industry standards in the design, construction and operation of the refrigeration system. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. Michael Foods Norwalk is required to and has implemented a Facility Emergency Response Plan. If an emergency was to occur, we have trained personnel and equipment ready for response in the event of a spill of hazardous materials. It is also our policy to notify the Norwalk Iowa Fire Department (via the 911 system) and the Warren County Emergency Response in the event of an emergency.



This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and will comply with all applicable state codes and regulations. Michael Foods Norwalk takes a systematic, proactive approach to evaluating chemical processes. Using this approach, the design, technology, operation and maintenance activities, emergency preparedness plans, training, process changes, and other elements that affect the covered processes are all considered. By conducting thorough evaluations, accidental releases are prevented and the consequences of releases are minimized.



By fulfilling the required elements of the RMP standards, Michael Foods Norwalk intends to prevent releases of hazardous substances and minimize the impacts of accidental releases, especially into locations that could expose employees, the community or the environment to serious hazards. Our management systems address each of the key features of a successful release prevention program including:



-Maintaining Process Safety Information (PSI): Michael Foods Norwalk maintains up-to date technical information about safe operating limits of the processes and associated hazards of the chemicals involved.

-Conducting Process Hazard Analyses (PHA): Michael Foods Norwalk performs technical analysis of the plant's processes in order to anticipate what might go wrong and recommend approached to minimize the possibilities and affects of such occurrences.

-Standard Operating Procedures (SOP): We have written technical and administrative procedures used to operate the plant safety.

-Training: Michael Foods Norwalk provides employees with information necessary to ensure safe operation.

-Mechanical Integrity: We ensure proper maintenance of the process equipment on an on-going basis.

-Management of Change (MOC): Michael Foods Norwalk analyzes changes in process equipment, procedures and personnel to understand the impact of those changes in the safe operation of our plant.

-Pre-Startup Safety Review: We ensure all necessary elements for operating a safe process are in place prior to introducing the hazardous chemical into a new or modified system.

-Compliance Audits: We conduct periodic evaluation and updating of the process operation to ensure all RMP elements are being applied properly.

-Incident Investigation: Michael Foods Norwalk has procedures for investigating the causes of near-miss or accidental releases and developing measures to prevent future similar occurrences.

-Employee Participation: We maintain a philosophy and approach to incorporating the knowledge and experience of our employees from all facets of operation regarding the covered processes.

-Hot Work Permit: We have a documented program for controlling the hazards associated with ignition source activities, thereby minimizing potential catastrophic release.

-Contractors: Michael Foods Norwalk upholds policies and procedures for ensuring safe work practices of contractors on the facility and a systematic approach of communicating hazards inherent to the covered processes which the contractor may be working on or near.



Our Company and our employees are committed to the standards that the RMP reg

ulation sets. We do business and have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting high standards for accident prevention. Michael Foods Norwalk has also developed a risk management system which identifies specific job positions and responsibilities to ensure proper management and implementation of this RMP.
